postsData.content:
𝗛𝗼𝘄 𝗼𝗳𝘁𝗲𝗻 𝗱𝗼 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝘀𝗮𝘆, “𝗜 𝗵𝗮𝘃𝗲 𝘁𝗼” 𝗶𝗻𝘀𝘁𝗲𝗮𝗱 𝗼𝗳 “𝗜 𝗴𝗲𝘁 𝘁𝗼”?

The way we frame our responsibilities shapes how we experience them.

A “have to” mindset makes tasks feel like burdens.

But when we shift to a “get to” perspective, we find gratitude, purpose, and even joy in the everyday.

Instead of:
 “I have to go to work.”
Try: “I get to contribute to something meaningful.”

Instead of:
 “I have to clean the house.”
Try: “I get to create a space of peace and comfort.”

Shifting your mindset takes practice, but here are some helpful tips:

 Lift Your Mindset Weight
Train your brain like a muscle. Keep reframing “have to” into “get to.”

 Break it Down
Small steps make big tasks feel manageable.

 Find Your Rhythm
Add movement, music, or fun to mundane tasks.

 Challenge Negative Thoughts
Replace complaints with affirmations.

 Practice Gratitude
Your life could change in an instant; appreciate what you have.

We can’t always control our responsibilities, but we can control how we approach them.

Where in your life can you shift from have to → get to?

Found this helpful? Repost to share with your network. ️

Followfor more insights on Leadership and Startup Growth. ️

postsData.content:
9 Insider Secrets to Make Your Boss Your Biggest Supporter

Your boss isn't just another relationship at work.
They're the catalyst for your next big opportunity.

But here's what most people miss:
It's not about being the perfect employee.
It's about being their trusted, strategic partner.

Here are 9 ways to build genuine trust with your boss:

1. Master the 30-Second Update
↳ Outcome + Why It Matters + Next Step
↳ If you can’t get to the point fast, you’ll lose them.

2. Become Part of Their Success Story
↳ Become an ally, don't just think of your success
↳ That's how you become the person they brag about

3. Be the Problem Solver They Didn't Know They Needed
↳ Spot issues before they surface
↳ Offer solutions before they ask

4. Understand Their Invisible Pressures
↳ The stressors they can't discuss openly?
↳ Those are are your opportunities to add value

5. Focus on Outcomes, Not Activities
↳ They care about results.
↳ Instead of: "I have completed my 20-page report"
↳ Say: "The report uncovered a 20% inefficiency, here’s how we can fix it"

6. Reduce Their Workload, Don't Add To It
↳ Before asking, ask yourself:
↳ Can I handle this independently?

7. Push Back Strategically
↳ Be bold and say no when it matters
↳ However, present alternatives that make "yes" easy

8. Think Like an Owner
↳ Employees wait to be told what to do.
↳ Owners see what needs to be done and do it.
↳ Bosses notice the difference.

9. Make Them Feel Like a Genius
↳ Build on their thinking instead of shutting it down
↳ Make them feel smart, not stupid or unwanted

These aren't your typical "work harder" tips.
They're proven strategies I've seen transform my own career at P&G and Amazon, and then my clients' too.

Which of these points surprised you the most? Share in the comments.

 Share this with your network to support them.
 Followmore strategic career insights that actually work

comments.commentText:

postsData.name:
Sam Jacobs
Sam Jacobs
postsData.content:
Dear aspiring CROs: Hitting the number is not enough.

The job of the CRO is not just to hit the number but to know WHY you hit it.

If you can’t explain why you hit the number…

If you can’t walk through what you did, what systems you put in place…

If you can’t demonstrate that you know how the machinery actually works…

Well, then, you just got lucky.

Congratulations.

I’d rather be lucky than good any day of the week.

But understand—

The Board is looking to invest.

And to make investments, they (and we) need confidence that you know how to spend the investment.

What’s the best way to do that?

For starters: Top down analysis is not enough.

Unless your business is truly a massive SMB business, knowing a few talking points about conversion rates is not enough.

You need to know the actual deals.

You need to understand the sales motion of your sellers.

What they’re saying.

What they’re hearing.

You need to be intimately familiar with every major Closed Won opportunity (at minimum) and all the important Closed Lost.

And, importantly, be able to show that something you did - some process, training, or hire - was the reason that a particular deal moved forward.

You need to be able to build a bottoms up and a top down forecast

Whether we’re in the age of efficiency or growth, one thing is true:

The bar is raised and the CROs that thrive in today’s market (like) have a plan, have communicated that plan, and know what parts of the plan worked or didn’t, how that led to results, and what they’re doing next to fix or improve.

You’ve gotta be conversant.

You’ve gotta know your sh*t.

Period.

Full stop.

“Let me get back to you on that” when someone asks a simple question about a specific sales cycle.

No, that won’t work.

Not anymore.
postsData.commentAdded: Great insights! A successful CRO goes beyond numbers—its all about understanding the why and having a solid plan to drive results. 💡

postsData.content:
Most people think success requires constant positivity and believing everything will work out right now. But that’s wrong because:

 Short-term optimism can lead to frustration. When things don’t go smoothly, people assume they’re failing and give up too soon.

 Expecting an easy path sets you up for disappointment. Challenges are part of the process, not signs that you’re on the wrong track.

 Blind positivity ignores the power of preparation. If you expect obstacles, you won’t be derailed by them.

There’s a better way:

 Be pessimistic in the short term—expect setbacks, challenges, and failures. They’re normal.

 Be optimistic in the long term—trust that if you keep showing up, adapting, and learning, success is inevitable.

Most people quit too soon because they expect short-term ease instead of short-term struggle. But the real winners? They stay in the game.

 What’s your take—do you agree or disagree? Let’s discuss in the comments.

comments.commentText: Risa Haasbroek Risa, this hits right at the core of perseverance!  Short-term pessimism isn’t defeat; it’s preparation for the dance with life’s chaos. ↗️ Staying optimistic in the long term while embracing those inevitable setbacks creates unshakable resilience. This reminds me of the ancient wisdom from the Bhagavad Gita— face the battle without attachment to immediate results.

postsData.name:
Elizabeth Renter
Elizabeth Renter
postsData.content:
The overall read on the labor market today is: continued strength. There are many countervailing factors in the data for January, from numerous revision types to wildfires and winter weather. These things make the story the data tells difficult to parse, and it’s best to examine the new release as a snapshot, rather than a comparison to prior months.

The January unemployment rate is little impacted by the revisions, and remains low. While the data indicates we added fewer jobs last month, we knew the previous figures were likely a little optimistic, so this shouldn’t come as a surprise. And even though it came in lower than expected, it shouldn’t be alarming.

Last summer we received the preliminary benchmark revisions, and there were some misunderstandings about what those changes meant. Now, we have the official revisions in-hand. Estimates like those found in the jobs report are often revised, and there were several revision types happening this month in the labor market data. Benchmarking refers to the process of aligning this frequent (monthly) data with more comprehensive but less frequent data. The end result is more accurate estimates. Revisions like this are not corrections, but improvements, and their usage is not new. If anything, they represent a strict commitment to data quality.
postsData.commentAdded: Great insights! Understanding labor market nuances is key. Accurate data revisions enhance our view on employment trends—thank you for sharing!

postsData.content:
Leadership Tip: The Power of Consistency Over Motivation

When it comes to effective leadership, motivation often gets the spotlight. While motivation can spark action, it’s consistency that sustains progress and drives long-term success.

Motivation is fleeting—it comes and goes, influenced by emotions, circumstances, and external factors. Consistency, however, is a habit, a disciplined commitment to show up, put in the effort, and lead with purpose, even on the days when motivation is nowhere to be found.
Great leaders aren't always the most inspired; they're the most consistent. They set clear expectations, follow through on commitments, and model steady, reliable behaviors that their teams can count on. This consistency fosters trust, builds credibility, and creates a culture where excellence is the norm.

If you find yourself waiting for motivation to strike, shift your focus. Create routines, establish non-negotiable habits, and lead by example. Consistency compounds over time, transforming small daily actions into extraordinary results.

Remember: Motivation gets you started. Consistency keeps you going.
postsData.commentAdded: Absolutely agree! Consistency is the backbone of leadership. It builds trust and drives lasting success. Lets lead with purpose every day!

postsData.name:
Lucas Wilson
Lucas Wilson
postsData.content:
The CEO’s Biggest Enemy: Distraction

If you’re leading a business—especially in a turnaround—you will be pulled in a hundred different directions. The noise, the fires, the urgent-but-not-important tasks will fight for your attention. And if you’re not ruthless in staying focused on what truly moves the business forward, you’ll pay for it.

I know this firsthand. I let distractions take my focus off the key levers of growth. In January, I missed our revenue forecast. Not how I wanted to start the year. But here’s the reality:

 A miss is a symptom. The real problem is what caused it.
At the end of the day, as a leader, you cannot afford to miss on three core pillars:

 OPEX – Running the Business: Cash flow, operational efficiency, and ensuring the team has the resources they need. This is about keeping the engine running without excess drag.
 New Revenue Growth: No business survives without consistent, scalable growth. When distractions pull you away from the real drivers of revenue—pipeline, sales execution, and partnerships—you feel it.
 Churn & Retention: New revenue means nothing if you can’t keep the customers you fought to win. The best companies aren’t just great at selling, they’re relentless in keeping and expanding customers.

 So here’s my hard-earned lesson: Distraction is the most expensive mistake a leader can make. It doesn’t hit you immediately, but when it does, the cost is undeniable.

A CEO/founder once told me something I’ll never forget:

“At the end of it, there’s an invoice due. And you are not going to want to pay it.”

That invoice? It’s the cost of allowing distraction to creep into your world. And when the bill comes, it’s painful.

February is about ruthless focus. No wasted time, no side quests, no unnecessary noise. Every hour, every decision, every meeting needs to serve one of these three pillars.

If you’re leading a team, a department, or a company—where are distractions pulling you away from what actually moves the needle?
postsData.commentAdded: Absolutely spot on! Maintaining focus is crucial for long-term success. Thanks for sharing this valuable insight on leadership!

postsData.content:
Stay Safe from Hackers! 

Hey everyone,

I recently came across some shocking new techniques that hackers are using to steal our money by getting access to our OTPs (One-Time Passwords). It's alarming how quickly they can fool us, and it's crucial that we stay vigilant and aware.

Check out this video to see how they do it and learn how you can protect yourself. Remember, awareness is our first line of defense against these scams!

Key Tips to Keep Your Money Safe:
1. Never share your OTP: No legitimate company or person will ever ask for it.
2. Use secure and complex passwords: Avoid using easily guessable information like birthdays.
3. Enable two-factor authentication: It adds an extra layer of security.
4. Be cautious of suspicious messages: Verify the source before taking any action.

Let's spread the word and protect ourselves and our loved ones from these threats. Share this post to raise awareness—together, we can make a difference!

comments.commentText: I've seen far too many reports of OTP thefts lately, let's educate those around us.

postsData.commentAdded: Great insights! Staying informed and vigilant is key. Lets all commit to protecting our digital presence and spreading the word! 🛡️ #CyberSecurity

"Education is not just about academic excellence—it's about creating pathways of opportunity and fostering inclusive leadership that transforms lives and communities."

A few days ago, I had the privilege of meeting Deanfromand. I graduated prior to Dean Behnam's appointment, this was the first time I had the opportunity to meet him in person, and it was an inspiring encounter

Having heard so much about his impactful work, it was exciting to finally connect with the visionary behind such transformative initiatives. Dean Behnam’s contributions include transforming the Sawyer Business School at Suffolk University in Boston into an institution with a global focus on experiential learning, as well as leading diversity and inclusion efforts. Under his leadership, the school not only saw increased enrollment but also forged meaningful international partnerships.

Reflecting on my own time at Loyola, I can confidently say that pursuing my MBA there was one of the most valuable experiences of my life. It was an inclusive and inspiring journey, especially as an immigrant, that laid a strong foundation for both my personal and professional growth. I deeply value the education I received and am excited to continue contributing to Loyola's growth and its mission of shaping future leaders beyond themselves.

We also had an insightful conversation about the benefits of experiential learning, and I was thrilled to learn more about—a unique two-year program at Loyola that provides affordable and accessible education to underserved students, particularly first-generation college students and those from low-income backgrounds.

Arrupe College’s mission is to offer a rigorous, Jesuit-inspired liberal arts education, creating a pathway for students to earn an associate's degree and either transfer to a four-year institution or enter the workforce. The program's affordability, strong community support, and commitment to social justice make it a remarkable initiative.

The picture captures a memorable sunset meeting with Deanand. As an alum, I’m excited to contribute to Loyola’s continued growth, especially in supporting initiatives like Arrupe College that empower the next generation of leaders.

Devraj Gorai

postsData.content:
India: A Market Ready to Explode

India: A Booming Market with Unprecedented Potential ️ 

With a population exceeding 1.4 billion, India stands as a global economic powerhouse, offering unparalleled market opportunities for businesses worldwide. This dynamic nation boasts a burgeoning middle class, rapid economic growth, and a youthful, tech-savvy population, creating a fertile ground for innovation and expansion.

️ Key Drivers of India's Market Growth:
1. Massive Consumer Base: India's vast population, coupled with rising disposable incomes, fuels robust consumer demand across diverse sectors, from consumer durables and electronics to healthcare and financial services.
2. Digital Revolution: India is witnessing a digital revolution, with rapid smartphone penetration and increasing internet connectivity. This digital wave is driving e-commerce, online services, and digital marketing, creating new avenues for businesses to connect with consumers.
3. Government Initiatives: The Indian government is actively promoting economic growth through initiatives like "Make in India," focusing on manufacturing and attracting foreign investment. Infrastructure development, ease of doing business reforms, and a focus on renewable energy are further bolstering the country's economic landscape.
4. A Young and Dynamic Workforce: India boasts a young and skilled workforce, eager to embrace new technologies and contribute to the nation's economic progress. This demographic dividend presents a significant opportunity for businesses to tap into a pool of talented professionals.

 Navigating the Indian Market:
While India presents immense opportunities, businesses must navigate certain challenges:
1. Competitive Landscape: The Indian market is highly competitive, with both domestic and international players vying for market share.
2. Infrastructure Gaps: While improving, infrastructure challenges such as power shortages, logistics bottlenecks, and inadequate transportation networks still persist in some regions.
3. Regulatory Complexity: Navigating India's complex regulatory environment can be challenging for businesses.

Despite these challenges, India remains an incredibly attractive market for businesses seeking growth and expansion. By understanding the unique dynamics of the Indian market, adapting to local needs, and leveraging the country's strengths, businesses can capitalize on the immense potential of this burgeoning economy. LinkedIn is, without a doubt, the highest-leverage platform for lead generation right now.

Most people don’t realize they’re sitting on a GOLDMINE of potential…

…and today, I’m about to show exactly how to tap into it:

It comes down to 5 key elements:

1. You need something worth selling

Nothing else matters if people can’t see a clear path to 5x ROI from your offer.

Start by building a service people actually want.

2. Your profile must reflect your expertise

Your LinkedIn profile isn’t just a resume—

It’s a credibility multiplier that needs to convert attention into real opportunities.

3. Content creates brand awareness

Every post should establish you as an authority in your space.

Skip the engagement bait and focus on expertise-driven content.

4. Outreach requires strategy

With only up to 300-400 monthly connection requests available, each one must count.

This goes without saying, but don’t use automations—they’re not only ineffective, but can get your account in trouble.

Send manual connection requests to folks with lots of connections in common via LinkedIn’s recommendations.

Pro tip: if you go to someone’s profile you’d like to connect with, LinkedIn will also recommend similar accounts.

5. Value outweighs sales gimmicks

You don’t need elaborate rapport-building schemes when you have real and immediate value to offer.

Mature business owners recognize an opportunity when it’s there.

Put these elements together correctly…

…and the results can (and will) be transformative.

This process has helped my clients add $25,000/month (and beyond) to their pipeline, no matter where they started.

postsData.content:
I've helped top companies close over $155M in ARR

Using a proven cold-calling script

It's guaranteed to lead to 1 meeting per day

Here's how it works:

1. You start with a pattern interrupt.
→ Grab attention in the first 10 seconds.
→ Acknowledge the cold call & get permission.

2. You transition with a qualifying question.
→ “As the (title), do you care about (pain point)?”
→  Or...“Do you already work through (challenge)?"
→  "Like (competitor 1] or (competitor 2) does?”

3. You "poke the pain" before pitching to them.
→  Ask a question that makes them feel it deeply.
→  Name issue → describe pain → define the cost.

4. You create curiosity, not resistance from them.
→ “Have you considered [solution] for [benefit]?”
→  Use an analogy: “It’s like a fire alarm for...”

5. Close with a simple, no-pressure ask of them.
→ “Would it be crazy for us to find 30 mins?”
→  Offer two-time slots to make it easier.

This is how you book more meetings.

+ How you drive more revenue in 2025.

Grab my step-by-step script here:



PS: What’s been your most memorable call?

postsData.content:
Introvert hangovers are real.
And they hit harder than you think.
Our brains process stimulation differently.


Here are 16 introvert hangovers you will want to avoid.

1️⃣ The Social Hangover

Too much small talk.
Too many interactions.

By the time you get home,
you feel completely drained.

↳ Plan recovery time before and after big social events.
↳ Choose smaller gatherings over large crowds.


2️⃣ The Overthinking Spiral

Did I say that right?
Did they misunderstand me?
Why did I phrase it like that?

Your brain replays the conversation on a loop. Exhausting.

↳ Remind yourself: Not every moment defines you.


3️⃣ The People-Pleasing Burnout

Too many yeses.
Not enough energy left.

You wanted to be helpful.
Now you just feel resentful.

↳ Try: “I’d love to help, but my plate is full.”


4️⃣ The Authenticity Gap

Faking extroversion to fit in?
Drains your energy fast.

↳ Show up as yourself.
↳ Let your strengths do the talking.


5️⃣ The Multitasking Crash

Juggling too much at once?
Your brain is fried.

↳ Focus on one deep task at a time.


6️⃣ The Meeting Drain

Back-to-back meetings with no time to think?

↳ Block quiet work time on your calendar.
↳ Take breaks between calls.


7️⃣ The Open-Space Overload

Constant noise.
Zero privacy.

↳ Use noise-canceling headphones.


8️⃣ The Small Talk Trap

Surface-level chatter that goes on forever.

↳ Steer the conversation toward topics you enjoy.


9️⃣ The Spotlight Fatigue

Being put on the spot with no time to prepare?

↳ Ask for agendas ahead of meetings.
↳ Buy yourself time with, “Let me think about that.”


 The Decision Fatigue

Too many choices.
Too little mental energy left.

↳ Simplify your options.


1️⃣1️⃣ The Weekend Recovery That Never Happens

A packed weekend leaves you more drained than the workweek.

↳ Protect your alone time.


1️⃣2️⃣ The Networking Exhaustion

Big events,
endless introductions, and
forced interactions.

↳ Focus on one meaningful conversation.


1️⃣3️⃣ The “Always Available” Trap

Responding instantly to every message?
Burns you out.

↳ Set response times.
↳ Turn off notifications when focusing.


1️⃣4️⃣ The Social Media Drain

Scrolling for too long leaves you overstimulated,
not recharged.

↳ Unfollow accounts that drain you.


1️⃣5️⃣ The No-Boundaries Burnout

Your time and energy get taken because you let them.

↳ Set limits.
↳ Protect your focus.


1️⃣6️⃣ The "Too Much Talking" Crash

Too many conversations,
even great ones,
leave you exhausted.

↳ Balance deep conversations with alone time.

Introverts, listen up!
Your energy is your greatest asset.

→ Protect it.
→ Manage it.
→ Own it.

 Lean into your strengths.
 Set better boundaries.
 And watch what happens.


I am Sven, and my mission is to help introverted entrepreneurs and professionals thrive as they are while protecting their energy to focus on their dreams.

postsData.content:
They said "the real estate market is dead" in 2008.

I watched my thriving title company face the biggest crisis of my generation.

Fellow business owners were in tears: "I'm losing everything. The market is crashing. I don't know if I can survive this."


But here's what 15 years of market cycles taught me:

Industries don't die. They transform.

And those who adapt don't just survive—they thrive.


In 2009, while others were grieving the "death" of real estate, I discovered something powerful:

Online Marketing.

So I closed up my title company and went all in. I figured I've grown other successful businesses, I just have to learn how it works and I'll be right back up there.

Don't get me wrong, starting over in a whole new industry... at the bottom... is absolutely no fun.

And it will challenge your ego to no end.


But here's the truth about market disruptions:

- Your value isn't tied to one industry
- Your skills can transfer anywhere
- Your ability to adapt is your greatest asset


Look at today's AI "crisis":

→ Some marketers are panicking
→ Others are slashing their prices
→ Many are fighting against change



Meanwhile, the smart ones are:

↳ Learning to leverage AI
↳ Upgrading their strategies
↳ Solving bigger problems


Because here's what most miss:

The market doesn't reward resistance. It rewards resilience.

If marketing disappeared tomorrow, I could... I don't know...

 Start a farm
 Launch a Gluten Free food brand
 Build something new


Why?

Because success isn't about the industry.

It's about your ability to:

 Spot opportunities
 Solve problems
 Serve people


The question isn't whether more disruption is coming—it is.

The question is: Will you let it break you, or make you better?


- Audra ️

postsData.name:
Paul Lister
Paul Lister
postsData.content:
Scrum team health checks are often a tickbox exercise with teams being asked to rate elements like events with the result not really helping teams to improve their lot.
But if the questions are chosen carefully and the score system promotes improvement then a nice visual 'team DNA' can be created. The questions are divided up into three basic production columns; ideation, creation, validation. These questions are answered using definitions that help to identify where coaching may be needed. The answers are colour coded and hence can be represented in a DNA style strip again which can direct teams and coaches to the areas where enhancements can be made.
Although the questions I have used do not formally contain the Scrum values or theory they tend to be implicit in the questions.
The question answers also have a numerical score but this does not tell us as much as the visualisation. Two teams can have the same score but have problems in different areas.
Feel free to try this with your teams, or amend the questions accordingly for your own agile ecosphere !

If you think this might be useful to your teams then you can copy the miro board (annotated with instructions) here:
postsData.commentAdded: Great insights on enhancing team health checks! Visualizing team DNA can truly pinpoint areas for growth. Excited to explore this approach! 🚀

postsData.content:
Most sales onboarding programs are a joke. 

Yep. I said it. Feeling fiesty on this friday morning.

They consist of...

- little bit of product knowledge
- basic HR stuff
- 'Go Shadow' type instructions - Listen to some calls.
- 2-5 days of 'training'
- maybe a role play here or there.

Then the good ole fashioned 'go get em tiger'

This aint the way ya'll.

I think one of the reasons I'm so fired up right now is because we just completed* (it never really ends, they aren't done yet!) the first officialSales Academy cohorts - led by

They crushed it.

What does this acadmey look like?

- 3 INTENSE weeks
- 100s of repetitions of every section of the messaging - Intro, Permission, Justifier, Bucket, MMS, etc. 100s.
- DEEP Prospect Knowledge and Training
- Product knowledge with the STFW test completed.
- Daily Practice - Talking hours of it.
- Daily EOD Reports sent to my self on Tone, Activity, Attentiveness, Coachability, etc
- Scripting and Call Scores write outs.
- Tone focus and repetition
- The Core 4 then Elite 8 Objection handling.
- Leveraging AI and good ole fashioned hand writing.

All cumulating to a call certification where they have to pass the call cert with myself or my VP.

All of them passed. Almost all of them then booked a meeting their first day on the phones, and are continuing to book now!

This is what sets people up for a long successful career.

This is what actually gets someone READY for their job.

This is what helps people feel confident in their role and be excited to execute.

Take the time to map this out.

If you don't have someone to lead it, spread it across the team and managers, Tribal Training style.

But I'll ask you this question.

Who do you think is better in the long run.

A rep that goes through the 'old way of onboarding'?

Or a rep that goes through the Academy above?

The choice is yours.

Proud of these new SDRs, BRIGHT future coming their way...

postsData.content:
I don’t care if you start at 9 AM sharp.

I don’t care if you work from home, a coffee shop, or your car.

I care about one thing: results.

If I hired you, it’s because I trust you.

I expect you to take ownership, deliver, and do your best work - however that looks for you.

That means:

 You don’t need to justify a day off.
 You don’t need to explain why you’re logging off early.
 You don’t need to feel guilty for having a life outside of work.

Life happens.

We’re all human.

Leadership isn’t about control.

It’s about empowerment.

Want to build a culture of trust?

Do this:

1/ Hire for values, not just skills
↳ A strong resume means nothing without the right mindset.

2/ Set clear expectations
↳ Ambiguity breeds frustration. Be specific about deliverables and goals.

3/ Give people the resources to thrive
↳ If they’re stuck, it’s your job to unblock them.

4/ Step back and trust them
↳ Nothing kills motivation faster than micromanagement.

 Trust people, and they’ll do their best work.
 Control them, and they’ll leave.

Because great teams don’t happen by accident.

They happen by design.

- - -

P.S. Have you ever left a job because of lack of freedom?

The table you sit at could be sabotaging your career.

Because when you participate in gossip

Gossip is magnetic:

 It provides a false sense of belonging

And comes with many dangers:

 Negativity impacts your mindset.
 It puts your reputation at risk.
 It erodes trust.

Don’t be a follower.

Choose integrity over gossip.

And build trust,

Not drama.

1/ Do not engage
↳ Excuse yourself or redirect the conversation

2/ Lead by example
↳ Not joining sends a powerful message about you

3/ Stick to facts and ideas
↳ Avoid discussing people if it means criticizing.

4/ Address it head on (the most courageous option)
↳ Speak directly to the gossiper.

5/ Do a relationships audit
↳ Remove toxic connections from your life

Remember:

If you want to be respected,

Surround yourself with people who lift you up,

Not tear others down.

‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾‾

postsData.content:
I killed 18 hours of meetings a week—and my clients thanked me for it.

2022 avg. hours per week in meetings: 20.3
2023 avg. hours per week in meetings. 1.8

What changed?

Are you ready? I’m about to lay out a super elaborate system.

…

I sent one email.

January 4, 2023, I messaged all staff and clients and said:

“Starting Feb. 1, I’m only accepting meetings on Tuesday and Thursday afternoons. I will politely decline if I’m invited to any meetings outside of those windows. All clients will receive a weekly Loom video instead.”

I sent the email because it had been one week since I burnt out so hard that I thought I was going to die.

I didn’t have the energy to fear the consequences.

But instead of mass anger, I got responses like:

“Good for you!”
“Sounds great!”
“Thanks for freeing up some time.”

Clients used to get 1-hour meetings per month.

They got a few 2-3 minute Loom videos instead.

75+ hours per month saved.

I know you’re in fear. I know this sounds crazy.

But what if doing less was MORE valuable?

The Looms were digestible, so clients watched them.

They didn’t have to pay attention for 60 minutes anymore.

It's easy to do nothing when you’re stuck with the status quo.

Or burn it down.

Maybe, just maybe, a moment of clarity (or, in my case, desperation) can yield a better result than you could have imagined.

That’s why I am telling you this story.

Whether you feel it or not, you’re in control right now.

You can turn your default agency into one designed for the life you want.

Get designing.

And if you’re on your own and not sure where to start, read this:

postsData.name:
Analytics / Data Science / AI Career
Analytics / Data Science / AI Career
postsData.content:
BIOMIMICRY CONTINUUM – Part 4 – Update Agent LEARNING
 Fundamental evidence of learning is the ability to recall and utilize what is learned. Receiving and integrating new information is a starting point. It is not learning, but an exceedingly small subset.
Recent research published in Nature uncovered that Concept Cells help our brain abstract information and build memories. (all links in my comment below)

A report in Quanta magazine provides an example: The idea of a “bank” has its own set of concept cells, maybe millions of them. Concept neurons fire for their concept no matter how it is presented: in real life or a photo, in text or speech, on television or in a podcast. “It’s more abstract, really different from what you’re seeing,” said Elizabeth Buffalo, a neuroscientist at the University of Washington.

These discoveries support and align with the abstraction methodology discussed in Part 2 and the contextualization methodology in Part 3 of this series.

In contrast to how the brain learns, LLMs:
-process all ingested data rather than filtering for relevance, and
-output the detailed words and pixels based on statistical proximity rather than conceptual value
The aim is to pass the Turing test, output that imitates the appearance of intelligence sufficiently to deceive the user.

The correctness of the result is dependent on the concentrations of relevant data in the training content. AI speed hides the fact that the model does not “know” anything but rather recomputes even identical prompts.

On the other hand, by imitating the learning and memory architecture and methodology of the brain the Agentic Expertise Ecosystem creates a library of reusable expertise and continues to learn. Imagine the applications when expertise is in high demand but sparse due to "brain drain" scenarios, new science and technology, or economic constraints.

In part 5 I will discuss the curation methodology.
postsData.commentAdded: Fascinating insights on the differences between brain learning and LLMs! Excited to see how the Agentic Expertise Ecosystem evolves in Part 5.

postsData.content:
3 harsh truths about RFPs:

1. If you didn't help write it, you're probably not going to win it

Most RFPs are won before they've even been released, due to vendors already influencing & shaping the RFP to their ideal requirements.

This is done through long-term & in-depth relationships, knowing why and when the customer is going to market.

Most customers don't really care for the RFP process - its usually an adminisrative headache that's a requirement over a certain $$$ investment.

Get ahead of the game by being part of your customers trusted network, knowing their strategic plans, lifecycles & planning solutions accoringly.

2. Most of it isn't going to get read anyways

Many RFP responses are generic marketing guff of 'best in class' & 'industry expertise' that customers eyes glaze over.

To get past the first round of responses you need to nail the executive summary, the compliance checklist & high-level investment summary.

Then when you're shortlisted you can refine responses and get into the real pre-sales process e.g. scoping the solution properly, business value & commercials.

3. You'll probably lose on price

Even if the criteria scorecard only says '20% scoring on price' you'll lose 80% of RFPs on price.

This is especially true in the public sector such as government departments or healthcare who basically mandate the cheapest option.

Most RFP responses are shaped to have very low margins on any hardware with margins made on professional services.

The real money is made in the back-end after you've won through "scope changes" or just accepting the deal as a loss-leader to get into the customer long-term.

Keep a firm eye on your proposal value and ensure its in a very competitive range to get past the first gatekeepers.

~~~

Struggling with Tech Sales as a non-Technical AE?

I've put the complete sales process that made a 2 x Top 1% AE without a tech degree in the free Tech Sales Mentorship here:

Kiran Babu
Kiran Babu
postsData.content:
Years ago, I met a man who had everything—wealth, connections, power. 
But he lost it all in an instant. Not because of bad luck, not because of the economy, but because he broke trust. 

One moment of dishonesty, one shortcut taken, one value compromised—and the empire he had spent years building collapsed like a house of cards.

Trust isn’t built overnight. It’s earned in drops, but lost in buckets.

Every single action you take is either making a deposit into your reputation or making a withdrawal. And if you’re not conscious of that, you’ll wake up one day wondering why people don’t believe in you, why opportunities slip away, and why success seems just out of reach.

Here's my take on the above scenario

1. Standards, Not Feelings, Dictate Your Reputation
Your reputation isn’t built on what you intend to do. It’s built on what you actually do—again and again and again. The little things count.

Every meeting you show up to on time, every promise you keep, every person you go out of your way to help. These small acts define you.

"Raise your standards, not just your expectations." If you want a reputation of excellence, live like it’s your non-negotiable standard. Treat your word like a contract. Deliver before the reminder. Show up when no one is watching.


2. Integrity is What You Do When No One’s Watching
Reputation doesn’t live in LinkedIn recommendations. It lives in the stories people tell when you’re not in the room. The world will talk about you—give them something worth saying.

"Trust isn’t about perfection, it’s about consistency." If you make a mistake, own it immediately. If you promise something, deliver it. And do it not because someone is keeping score, but because integrity is who you are.


3. What You Tolerate, You Teach
Ever noticed how people start treating you based on what you allow? If you tolerate excuses from yourself, people will expect less from you. If you cut corners, they’ll assume that’s your standard. But when you demand more from yourself, the world rises to meet you.

Decide today: Are you someone people trust? Or someone they question?
Protect your reputation like your future depends on it—because it does.

4. Be The Person Who Sets the Standard
The world is filled with excuses, with broken promises, with people who overpromise and underdeliver. Don’t be one of them. Be the person whose name carries weight. The person others count on. The one who follows through no matter what.

Because your reputation travels faster than you do. Make sure it carries your excellence—not your excuses.

Now, go out there and make every drop count!

comments.commentText: People forget what you say, but they never forget how you made them feel. Make sure every interaction adds to—not subtracts from—your legacy.

postsData.commentAdded: Wise words! Integrity and consistency truly shape our reputations. Let’s all strive to be the standard others aspire to meet!

postsData.name:
Aditi Singh
Aditi Singh
postsData.content:
Ever feel like you’re staring at a menu with 100 options and can’t decide what to order? 

Now imagine that same feeling, but with your life.

That’s the idea behind Sylvia Plath’s “fig tree” analogy.

Picture a tree full of ripe figs, each one representing a different path your life could take—one fig is your dream career, another is traveling the world, another is starting a family, and so on.

The problem?

You can only pick one.

And while you’re standing there, trying to decide, the figs start to shrivel and fall.

It’s a powerful way to describe that overwhelming feeling of having too many choices and being scared to commit.

What if you pick the wrong one? What if you miss out on something better?

But here’s the thing: life isn’t about picking the “perfect” fig. It’s about choosing one, savoring it, and making the most of it—even if you sometimes wonder about the others.

So, what fig are you reaching for? And how do you deal with the fear of missing out?

In collaboration with the NHRDN Delhi & NCR Chapter, G L Bajaj Institute of Management & Research (GLBIMR) successfully organized the HR 4.0 Conclave – "Shaping the Future of Work through Digital Transformation and AI" on 31 January 2025 at it's
Campus, Greater Noida.

The event began with a Presidential Address by, who shared key insights on the Future of Work, drawing from the2024 Work Reimagined Survey (conducted between July and August 2024).

 Key Takeaways from the Panel Discussion on 'Upskilling the Future Workforce', featuring,,,andand moderated by:
 The future workforce expects learning to be personalized, on-demand, and peer-driven.
 AI is enhancing jobs rather than replacing them and will continue to do so.
 Change readiness is just as vital as access to the right learning tools for effective upskilling.
 HR leaders are actively exploring AI applications in predictive workforce analytics and sentiment analysis.
 Emotional intelligence (EQ) and learning agility are crucial skills for students entering the workforce.

A huge thank you to our speakers, panelists, and attendees for making this a power-packed discussion!
